qas.question: The setting the mandolin was used in until the 1930's was?
Where did the mandolins find a new home?
What mandolin was designed to boost interest in the mandolin?

answers.text: Lloyd Loar Master Model from Gibson

qas.question: What mandolin became the face of bluegrass music?
What instrument did artist Bill Monroe use?
The setting the mandolin was used in until the 1940's was?
Where did the mandolins never find a new job?

plausible_answers.text: Lloyd Loar Master Model from Gibson

qas.question: What mandolin wasn't designed to boost interest in the mandolin?
What mandolin didn't become the face of bluegrass music?
What instrument didn't artist Bill Monroe use?

context: The instrument was primarily used in an <a0_0><b5_0>ensemble setting<b5_0/><a0_0/> well into the 1930s, and although the fad died out at the beginning of the 1930s, the instruments that were developed for the orchestra found a new home in <a1_0><b6_0>bluegrass<b6_0/><a1_0/>. The famous <a2_0><b7_0>Lloyd <b8_0>Loar<b8_0/> Master Model from Gibson<b7_0/><a2_0/> (1923) was designed to boost the flagging interest in mandolin ensembles, with little success. However, The "<a3_0>Loar<a3_0/>" became the defining instrument of bluegrass music when Bill Monroe purchased <a4_0><b9_0>F-5 S/N 73987<b9_0/><a4_0/> in a Florida barbershop in 1943 and popularized it as his main instrument.
